Description: The head of a horse, broken from a terracotta figure, with deep incisions indicating the mane, and a suspension-hole pierced through the cheeks; both ears are damaged. The animal seems very likely to have been made in a two-piece mould, but hand-modelling is a possibility. Micaceous light grey-brown clay, probably a marl ware, with an overall cream-buff slip and red-brown ceramic colour details along the mane and down the nose.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Qasr Ibrim (Nubia), North Plaza Floor 7
Curator's comments: Terracotta IV Donated: Egypt Exploration Society. Excavated at Qasr Ibrim, Northern Plaza, Floor 7. Excavation no. '[QI] 74.2.25/7'. Late Roman, sixth to seventh century AD.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3761)
Acquisition name: Division of Finds: Egyptian Antiquities Organisation
